posts.title: Building My First PC
posts.message:
After years of using a MacBook, I finally decided to build my own desktop PC from scratch — and it turned out amazing. I spent weeks researching parts, comparing prices, and learning about compatibility. The result? A powerful, efficient, and beautifully lit system that runs everything from game development to streaming with ease.

Here’s the full build on PCPartPicker:
https://pcpartpicker.com/b/YWcbt6

This build features an AMD Ryzen 7 7700X processor, Gigabyte B650 Gaming X AX V2 motherboard, G.Skill Flare X5 DDR5-6000 RAM, Peerless Assassin 120 SE cooler, and a Samsung 990 EVO Plus 1TB SSD — all wrapped up in a sleek Montech case. The experience of putting it together was both challenging and rewarding, and seeing it power on for the first time was one of the best feelings ever.

posts.title: Setting Up My Own Domain and Connecting It to GitHub
posts.message:
Today I officially set up my very own domain — thequantifier.com — and connected it to my GitHub Pages site. It’s something I’ve wanted to do for a while: having a clean, personal domain that links everything I create, from code to writing.

I registered the domain through Squarespace, which made the process simple and secure. After verifying ownership, I configured the DNS settings to point to GitHub’s servers and linked it directly to my repository. Within minutes, my site was live under its new name.

Now, I can host all my projects, portfolios, and experiments in one place — cleanly under my own banner. It feels awesome seeing thequantifier.com load up with my work. This marks the beginning of an even bigger personal web presence.

For anyone else setting this up: make sure your repository includes a CNAME file with your custom domain name (e.g., thequantifier.com) and double-check your DNS records for A and AAAA entries pointing to GitHub’s IPs. It’s worth the effort!
